Message.Issue: Change 'FoodRelated.CombinedFoodList' to be read-only by removing the property setter.
Change 'List<Tuple<string, double, double, string, bool>>' in 'FoodRelated.CombinedFoodList' to use Collection<T>, ReadOnlyCollection<T> or KeyedCollection<K,V>
Consider a design where 'FoodRelated.CombinedFoodList' doesn't nest generic type 'List<Tuple<string, double, double, string, bool>>'.

In member 'IModification.ModifyFoodPropertiesList(string[], decimal[], bool[])', consider replacing the language-specific data type identifier 'bool' in parameter name 'boolProperties' with a more generic term, such as 'value'.

In member 'IModification.ModifyFoodPropertiesList(string[], decimal[], bool[])', consider replacing the data type identifier 'string' in parameter name 'stringProperties' with a more generic term, such as 'value'.

Change 'PopupHandler.CreatePopup(string, int, bool, Control)' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Change 'Program.Application_ThreadException(object, ThreadExceptionEventArgs)' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Change 'Program.CurrentDomain_UnhandledException(object, UnhandledExceptionEventArgs)' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Change 'Program.Main(string[])' to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.

Rule.Name: Collection properties should be read only
Rule.Description: Properties that return collections should be read-only so that users cannot entirely replace the backing store. Users can still modify the contents of the collection by calling relevant methods on the collection. Note that the XmlSerializer class has special support for deserializing read-only collections. See the XmlSerializer overview for more information.
Rule.Resolution: Change {0} to be read-only by removing the property setter.

Rule.Name: Do not expose generic lists
Rule.Description: Do not expose List<T> in object models. Use Collection<T>, ReadOnlyCollection<T> or KeyedCollection<K,V> instead. List<T> is meant to be used from implementation, not in object model API. List<T> is optimized for performance at the cost of long term versioning. For example, if you return List<T> to the client code, you will not ever be able to receive notifications when client code modifies the collection.
Rule.Resolution: Change {0} in {1} to use Collection<T>, ReadOnlyCollection<T> or KeyedCollection<K,V>

Rule.Name: Do not nest generic types in member signatures
Rule.Description: Avoid API that require users to instantiate a generic type with another generic type as type argument. The syntax gets too complex.
Rule.Resolution: Consider a design where {0} doesn't nest generic type {1}.

Rule.Name: Identifiers should not contain type names
Rule.Description: Avoid using language-specific types name in parameters and members and data type identifiers in parameters. Types names might not be intuitive for all developers. It is recommended that you select a generic name, such as 'value', instead. If this is not sufficient, be sure to use the type name as it is defined in the .NET Framework Library and avoid language-specific type names completely. Some examples of C#-specific type names are 'float' (use 'Single' if a generic name is not sufficient), and 'ulong' (use 'UInt64' if a generic name is not sufficient).
Rule.Resolution: In member {0}, consider replacing the data type identifier '{1}' in parameter name {2} with a more generic term, such as 'value'.
In member {0}, consider replacing the language-specific data type identifier '{1}' in parameter name {2} with a more generic term, such as 'value'.

Rule.Name: Specify MessageBoxOptions
Rule.Description: In order to run correctly on right-to-left systems, all calls to MessageBox.Show should use the overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions as an argument. Programs should detect whether they are running on a right-to-left system at run-time and pass the appropriate MessageBoxOptions value in order to display correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Change {0} to call the MessageBox.Show overload that specifies MessageBoxOptions, and make sure to set MessageBoxOptions.RightAlign and MessageBoxOptions.RtlReading if RightToLeft is set to RightToLeft.Yes on the parent control.
